texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We have two Google Pixel phones in our house: a Pixel 2 and a Pixel 3. Both of them drop off our home wireless network regularly. It causes lots of problems with various applications on the phones, especially casting video via Chromecast.
texts.text: We have two Google Pixel phones in our house: a Pixel 2 and a Pixel 3. Both of them drop off our home wireless network regularly. It causes lots of problems with various applications on the phones, especially casting video via Chromecast.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At the time when I first noticed the drops, I was using a pair of wireless access points (APs) from Engenius:
texts.text: At the time when I first noticed the drops, I was using a pair of wireless access points (APs) from Engenius:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='EAP600'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='EAP600'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='EAP1200H'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='EAP1200H'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Also, here's what I knew at the time:
texts.text: Also, here's what I knew at the time:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Mac and Linux computers had no Wi-Fi issues at all
texts.text: Mac and Linux computers had no Wi-Fi issues at all

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The signal level from both APs was strong
texts.text: The signal level from both APs was strong

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Disabling one AP made no improvement
texts.text: Disabling one AP made no improvement

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Disabling one band (2.4 or 5GHz) on the APs made no improvement
texts.text: Disabling one band (2.4 or 5GHz) on the APs made no improvement

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Clearing the bluetooth/Wi-Fi data on the Pixel had no effect
texts.text: Clearing the bluetooth/Wi-Fi data on the Pixel had no effect

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Assigning a static IP address on the Pixel made no improvement
texts.text: Assigning a static IP address on the Pixel made no improvement

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Using unencrypted SSIDs made no improvement
texts.text: Using unencrypted SSIDs made no improvement

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At this point, I felt strongly that the APs had nothing to do with it. I ordered a new  NetGear Orbi  mesh router and satellite anyway. The Pixels still dropped off the wireless network even with the new Orbi APs.
texts.text: At this point, I felt strongly that the APs had nothing to do with it. I ordered a new  NetGear Orbi  mesh router and satellite anyway. The Pixels still dropped off the wireless network even with the new Orbi APs.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Reading logs
texts.text: Reading logs

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I started reading logs from every source I could find:
texts.text: I started reading logs from every source I could find:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: dhcpd logs from my router
texts.text: dhcpd logs from my router

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: syslogs from my APs (which forwarded into the router)
texts.text: syslogs from my APs (which forwarded into the router)

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: output from tcpdump on my router
texts.text: output from tcpdump on my router

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Several things became apparent after reading the logs:
texts.text: Several things became apparent after reading the logs:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The Wi-Fi drop occurred usually every 30-60 seconds
texts.text: The Wi-Fi drop occurred usually every 30-60 seconds

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The DHCP server received requests for a new IP address after every drop
texts.text: The DHCP server received requests for a new IP address after every drop

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: None of the network traffic from the phones was being blocked at the router
texts.text: None of the network traffic from the phones was being blocked at the router

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The logs from the APs showed the phone disconnecting itself from the
texts.text: The logs from the APs showed the phone disconnecting itself from the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All of the wireless and routing systems in my house seemed to point to a problem in the phones themselves. They were voluntarily dropping from the network without being bumped off by APs or the router.
texts.text: All of the wireless and routing systems in my house seemed to point to a problem in the phones themselves. They were voluntarily dropping from the network without being bumped off by APs or the router.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Getting logs from the phone
texts.text: Getting logs from the phone

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It was time to get some logs from the phone itself. That would require connecting the phone via USB to a computer and enabling USB debugging on the phone.
texts.text: It was time to get some logs from the phone itself. That would require connecting the phone via USB to a computer and enabling USB debugging on the phone.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First, I downloaded the  Android SDK . The full studio release isn't needed -- scroll down and find the  Command line tools only  section. Unzip the download and find the
texts.text: First, I downloaded the  Android SDK . The full studio release isn't needed -- scroll down and find the  Command line tools only  section. Unzip the download and find the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: tools/bin/sdkmanager
texts.text: tools/bin/sdkmanager

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: executable. Run it like this:
texts.text: executable. Run it like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# Fedora 29 systems may need to choose the older Java version for sdkmanager
# to run properly.
export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.201.b09-2.fc29.x86_64/jre
# Install the android-28 platform tools
./sdkmanager "platform-tools" "platforms;android-28"
texts.text:
# Fedora 29 systems may need to choose the older Java version for sdkmanager
# to run properly.
export JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.201.b09-2.fc29.x86_64/jre
# Install the android-28 platform tools
./sdkmanager "platform-tools" "platforms;android-28"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now we need to enable USB debugging on the phone itself.  Be sure to disable USB debugging when you are done!  Follow these steps:
texts.text: Now we need to enable USB debugging on the phone itself.  Be sure to disable USB debugging when you are done!  Follow these steps:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go into the phone's settings and choose
texts.text: Go into the phone's settings and choose

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Scroll to the bottom and tap the
texts.text: Scroll to the bottom and tap the

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Go back one screen and tap
texts.text: Go back one screen and tap

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click
texts.text: Click

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: In the
texts.text: In the

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Connect the phone to your computer via USB and run:
texts.text: Connect the phone to your computer via USB and run:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sudo platform-tools/adb logcat
texts.text: sudo platform-tools/adb logcat

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your screen will fill with logs from your phone.
texts.text: Your screen will fill with logs from your phone.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Nuggets in the log
texts.text: Nuggets in the log

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I watched the logs and waited for the Wi-Fi to drop. As soon as it dropped, I saw some interesting log messages:
texts.text: I watched the logs and waited for the Wi-Fi to drop. As soon as it dropped, I saw some interesting log messages:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
I wpa_supplicant: wlan0: CTRL-EVENT-AVOID-FREQ ranges=5785-5825
I chatty  : uid=1000(system) IpClient.wlan0 expire 3 lines
I chatty  : uid=1000 system_server expire 1 line
D CommandListener: Setting iface cfg
E cnss-daemon: wlan_service_update_sys_param: unable to open /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_use_userconfig
I chatty  : uid=1000(system) android.fg expire 1 line
I wpa_supplicant: wlan0: CTRL-EVENT-DISCONNECTED bssid=88:dc:96:4a:b6:75 reason=3 locally_generated=1
I chatty  : uid=10025 com.google.android.gms.persistent expire 7 lines
V NativeCrypto: Read error: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Software caused connection abort
V NativeCrypto: Write error: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Broken pipe
V NativeCrypto: Write error: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Broken pipe
V NativeCrypto: SSL shutdown failed: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Success
D ConnectivityService: reportNetworkConnectivity(158, false) by 10025
texts.text:
I wpa_supplicant: wlan0: CTRL-EVENT-AVOID-FREQ ranges=5785-5825
I chatty  : uid=1000(system) IpClient.wlan0 expire 3 lines
I chatty  : uid=1000 system_server expire 1 line
D CommandListener: Setting iface cfg
E cnss-daemon: wlan_service_update_sys_param: unable to open /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp_use_userconfig
I chatty  : uid=1000(system) android.fg expire 1 line
I wpa_supplicant: wlan0: CTRL-EVENT-DISCONNECTED bssid=88:dc:96:4a:b6:75 reason=3 locally_generated=1
I chatty  : uid=10025 com.google.android.gms.persistent expire 7 lines
V NativeCrypto: Read error: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Software caused connection abort
V NativeCrypto: Write error: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Broken pipe
V NativeCrypto: Write error: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Broken pipe
V NativeCrypto: SSL shutdown failed: ssl=0x7b349e2d08: I/O error during system call, Success
D ConnectivityService: reportNetworkConnectivity(158, false) by 10025

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The line with
texts.text: The line with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CTRL-EVENT-AVOID-FREQ
texts.text: CTRL-EVENT-AVOID-FREQ

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: isn't relevant because it's simply a hint to the wireless drivers to avoid certain frequencies not used in the USA. The
texts.text: isn't relevant because it's simply a hint to the wireless drivers to avoid certain frequencies not used in the USA. The

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CTRL-EVENT-DISCONNECTED
texts.text: CTRL-EVENT-DISCONNECTED

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: shows where wpa_supplicant received the disconnection message. The last line with
texts.text: shows where wpa_supplicant received the disconnection message. The last line with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ConnectivityService
texts.text: ConnectivityService

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: was very interesting. Something in the phone believes there is a network connectivity issue. That could be why the Pixel is hopping off the wireless network.
texts.text: was very interesting. Something in the phone believes there is a network connectivity issue. That could be why the Pixel is hopping off the wireless network.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: From there, I decided to examine only the
texts.text: From there, I decided to examine only the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ConnectivityService
texts.text: ConnectivityService

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: logs:
texts.text: logs:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: sudo platform-tools/adb logcat 'ConnectivityService:* *:S'
texts.text: sudo platform-tools/adb logcat 'ConnectivityService:* *:S'

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This logcat line tells adb that I want all logs from all log levels about the
texts.text: This logcat line tells adb that I want all logs from all log levels about the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ConnectivityService
texts.text: ConnectivityService

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , but all of the other logs should be silenced. I started seeing some interesting details:
texts.text: , but all of the other logs should be silenced. I started seeing some interesting details:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
D ConnectivityService: NetworkAgentInfo [WIFI () - 148] validation failed
D ConnectivityService: Switching to new default network: NetworkAgentInfo{ ni{[type: MOBILE[LTE]...
D ConnectivityService: Sending DISCONNECTED broadcast for type 1 NetworkAgentInfo [WIFI () - 148] isDefaultNetwork=true
D ConnectivityService: Sending CONNECTED broadcast for type 0 NetworkAgentInfo [MOBILE (LTE) - 100] isDefaultNetwork=true
D ConnectivityService: handleNetworkUnvalidated NetworkAgentInfo [WIFI () - 148] ...
texts.text:
D ConnectivityService: NetworkAgentInfo [WIFI () - 148] validation failed
D ConnectivityService: Switching to new default network: NetworkAgentInfo{ ni{[type: MOBILE[LTE]...
D ConnectivityService: Sending DISCONNECTED broadcast for type 1 NetworkAgentInfo [WIFI () - 148] isDefaultNetwork=true
D ConnectivityService: Sending CONNECTED broadcast for type 0 NetworkAgentInfo [MOBILE (LTE) - 100] isDefaultNetwork=true
D ConnectivityService: handleNetworkUnvalidated NetworkAgentInfo [WIFI () - 148] ...

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Wait, what is this "validation failed" message? The Pixel was making network connections successfully the entire time as shown by tcpdump. This is part of Android's [network connecivity checks] for various networks.
texts.text: Wait, what is this "validation failed" message? The Pixel was making network connections successfully the entire time as shown by tcpdump. This is part of Android's [network connecivity checks] for various networks.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The last few connections just before the disconnect were to
texts.text: The last few connections just before the disconnect were to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: connectivitycheck.gstatic.com
texts.text: connectivitycheck.gstatic.com

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (based on tcpdump logs) and that's Google's way of verifying that the wireless network is usable and that there are no captive portals. I connected to it from my desktop on IPv4 and IPv6 to verify:
texts.text: (based on tcpdump logs) and that's Google's way of verifying that the wireless network is usable and that there are no captive portals. I connected to it from my desktop on IPv4 and IPv6 to verify:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ curl -4 -i https://connectivitycheck.gstatic.com/generate_204
HTTP/2 204
date: Sun, 17 Mar 2019 15:00:30 GMT
alt-svc: quic=":443"; ma=2592000; v="46,44,43,39"
$ curl -6 -i https://connectivitycheck.gstatic.com/generate_204
HTTP/2 204
date: Sun, 17 Mar 2019 15:00:30 GMT
alt-svc: quic=":443"; ma=2592000; v="46,44,43,39"
texts.text:
$ curl -4 -i https://connectivitycheck.gstatic.com/generate_204
HTTP/2 204
date: Sun, 17 Mar 2019 15:00:30 GMT
alt-svc: quic=":443"; ma=2592000; v="46,44,43,39"
$ curl -6 -i https://connectivitycheck.gstatic.com/generate_204
HTTP/2 204
date: Sun, 17 Mar 2019 15:00:30 GMT
alt-svc: quic=":443"; ma=2592000; v="46,44,43,39"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Everything looked fine.
texts.text: Everything looked fine.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Heading to Google
texts.text: Heading to Google

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After a bunch of searching on Google, I kept finding posts talking about disabling IPv6 to fix the Wi-Fi drop issues. I shrugged it off and kept searching. Finally, I decided to disable IPv6 and see if that helped.
texts.text: After a bunch of searching on Google, I kept finding posts talking about disabling IPv6 to fix the Wi-Fi drop issues. I shrugged it off and kept searching. Finally, I decided to disable IPv6 and see if that helped.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I stopped
texts.text: I stopped

texts.label: code
texts.orig: radvd
texts.text: radvd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: on the router, disabled Wi-Fi on the phone, and then re-enabled it. As I watched, the phone stayed on the wireless network for two minutes. Three minutes. Ten minutes.  There were no drops.
texts.text: on the router, disabled Wi-Fi on the phone, and then re-enabled it. As I watched, the phone stayed on the wireless network for two minutes. Three minutes. Ten minutes.  There were no drops.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: At this point, this is still an unsolved mystery for me. Disabling IPv6 is a terrible idea, but it keeps my phones online. I plan to put the phones on their own VLAN without IPv6 so I can still keep IPv6 addresses for my other computers, but this is not a good long term fix. If anyone has any input on why this helps and how I can get IPv6 re-enabled, please  let me know !
texts.text: At this point, this is still an unsolved mystery for me. Disabling IPv6 is a terrible idea, but it keeps my phones online. I plan to put the phones on their own VLAN without IPv6 so I can still keep IPv6 addresses for my other computers, but this is not a good long term fix. If anyone has any input on why this helps and how I can get IPv6 re-enabled, please  let me know !

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Several readers wanted to see what was happening just before the Wi-Fi drop, so here's a small snippet from tcpdump:
texts.text: Several readers wanted to see what was happening just before the Wi-Fi drop, so here's a small snippet from tcpdump:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: That IPv6 address is at a Google PoP in Dallas, TX:
texts.text: That IPv6 address is at a Google PoP in Dallas, TX:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I haven't been able to intercept the traffic via man-in-the-middle since Google's certificate checks are very strict. However, checks from my own computer work without an issue:
texts.text: I haven't been able to intercept the traffic via man-in-the-middle since Google's certificate checks are very strict. However, checks from my own computer work without an issue:
